Tools - Regex

Created:2019-03-01  Last modified:2019-08-04

  • Introduction
  • Rules
  • References

  1. Introduction

    A regular expression (regex) is a sequence of characters that define a search pattern.

    The pattern is constructed with logic.

  2. Rules

    Wildcard

    1. . matches any character, but only match one.

    Boolean Or

    1. | hello|hi match either "hello" or "hi"

    Character Classes

    A special character matches a set of characters.

    1. \w: matches alphanumeric characters plus "_"
    2. \W: matches all characters except \w, (\w|\W) = .
    3. \d: matches all digitals
    4. \s: matches space
    5. user-defined character class with []:
      [aqsx] matches a|q|s|x
      [^aqsx] matches all except a|q|s|x
      [a-n] matches all a to n characters

    Grouping

    1. ():
      h(ello|i) => hello|hi => hello, hi
      (hi){2,3} => hihi, hihihi
    2. \1 back reference the first delimited group
      e.g. "Hello, Hello" will match H(ello|i),\sH\1. The first group matched "ello", then the \1 will be restricted to "ello"
      H(ello|i),\sH(ello|i) != H(ello|i),\sH\1, because the first one also matches "Hello, Hi"
    3. (?:) non-capturing group: back reference will ignore this the group with ?:
      (?:qin|nan) (has|had) a car. This car \1 a GPS equipment. // The \1 refers to (has|had) instead of (qin|nan)

    Lookaround (zero-width assertion)

    1. (?=) positive lookahead: the group must be matched but it is not included in the result
      "qin(?=\snan)" matches "qin nan", but the (?=\snan) only does an assertion, itself is not included in the result.
    2. (?!) negative lookahead: the group must not be matched
      "qin(?!\snan)" matches "qin others".
    3. (?<=) positive lookbehind
    4. (?<!) negative lookbehind: (?<!a)b matches a "b" that is not preceded by an "a"

    Quantification

    Specify the expected number of repeat

    1. *: 0 or more
    2. ?: 0 or 1
    3. +: 1 or more
    4. {}: user-defined quantification
      {3} exactly three, {3,5} repeat 3 to 5 times, {1, } at least once, {,4} four or less.
      "qin{0,2}an" => qian|qinan|qinnan
      "q\w*" => q....
      ".*" => match anything

    Anchor

    Specify the position of expected characters

    1. ^: expected the following character(s) at start position
      ^qin.* matches all strings starting with qin. (^qin only matches qin).
    2. $: expected the pervious character(s) at end position
      .*qin$ matches all strings ending with qin. (qin$ only matches qin).
    3. \b: word boundary break a string into "word", and the desired positions are at the beginning and end of a word.
      How to break a string into words?
      1). Before the first character in the string, if the first character is a word character.
      2). After the last character in the string, if the last character is a word character.
      3). Between two characters in the string, where one is a word character and the other is not a word character.] For example "How are you?" => "H...w...a...e...y...u", the last ? is not count as a boundary even through it is the last character.
      "Hello, Hi" => \bH matches two H
      "Hello, Hi" => \bH.*o\b matches Hello

    Escaped character

      \. \? \+ \* \\ \t \n \r
      regex "\\\?" matches string "\?"

  3. References

    1. https://regexr.com
